entry.et: Middle English forke, from Old English & Anglo-French; Old English forca & Anglo-French furke, from Latin furca

def.dt: :an implement with two or more prongs used especially for taking up (as in eating), pitching, or digging
:a forked part, tool, or piece of equipment
:a division into branches or the place where something divides into branches
:one of the branches into which something forks
:an attack by one chess piece (as a knight) on two pieces simultaneously
:to divide into two or more branches where the road forks
:to use or work with a fork
:to give the form of a fork to forking her fingers
:to raise, pitch, dig, or work with a fork fork hay
:pay contribute used with over, out, or up had to fork over $5000
:tender enough to be easily pierced or cut with a fork fork–tender filet mignon
:a 2-pronged metal implement that gives a fixed tone when struck and is useful for tuning musical instruments and ascertaining standard pitch
river 300 miles (483 kilometers) W Montana & N Idaho flowing NW into Pend Oreille Lake
